awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Modern Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer (SCXRD) to support Professor Wei You and colleagues Jeffrey Johnson, Alexander Miller, Jillian Dempsey and Aleksandr Zhukhovitskiy. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows for the accurate and precise determination of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules in the crystal lattice. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry, solar fuel production and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution as well as collaborators from other regional universities such as the University of North Carolina Greensboro, North Carolina Central University, Duke University, Elon University, Davidson College and East Carolina University.

The award of this diffractometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the development of chemical reactions and deployment of reaction strategies for the synthesis of bioactive natural products with an emphasis on sustainable catalysis. The instrumentation is used in the development of approaches to the sustainable synthesis of chemical building blocks and fuels and for improving efficiency in solar fuel production by optimizing fundamental electron transfer processes. In addition, it benefits studies of high-valent iron-oxo porphyrins that perform selective hydroxylations of unactivated sp3 hybridized carbon-hydrogen bonds and studies developing asymmetric methods for enantioselective synthesis of lactones and hydroxy esters. This diffractometer also benefits the exploration of catalysis for conjugated polymer synthesis, and the creation of  optoelectronic devices through the development of hybrid perovskites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF MRI grant for the Acquisition of a Modern Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer for Research and Education (CHE=2117287) was awarded in August 2021.  In October 2021, a decision was made to acquire the Bruker D8 VENTURE after evaluating options from various vendors to replace the outdated Bruker SMART APEXII system and effectively address research needs. The installation of the instrument, initially delayed by the COVID-19 pandemic and supply chain shortage, was completed in October 2022.

The Bruker D8 VENTURE features molybdenum and copper microfocus X-ray sources with shutterless detection, HELIOS MX multilayer optics for optimal beam intensity, and a highly sensitive Photon III detector, enabling data collection on very small crystals.  Its kappa-geometry goniometer offers flexible sample positioning, facilitating efficient data acquisition. The Oxford Cryostream 800 plus allows for experimental temperatures ranging from 80 to 500K.  Additional funding from the UNC Core Facilities Advocacy Committee (CFAC) was secured to upgrade the standard microfocus copper source to a microfocus copper DIAMOND source, which provides up to three times the intensity of the latest standard microfocus radiation source, enabling near-synchrotron quality data collection on macromolecular crystals.

The Bruker D8 VENTURE has been a crucial upgrade for the UNC X-ray Crystallography Core Laboratory, bolstering collaboration with researchers both within and outside the University.  Since its acquisition, the instrument has exceeded the initial sample generation estimate  of 210 samples per year, producing 256 samples in 2023 and 314 samples by October 2024.  This significant increase in usage can be attributed in part to an influx of samples from neighboring Universities, including Duke University, UNC-Greensboro, North Carolina State University, Wake Forest University, North Carolina Central University, as well as from institutions like Davidson College, Carnegie Mellon University, and University of Montana. The enhanced capabilities of the instrument support a wide range of high-impact research projects, as reflected in the resulting publication output.  Additionally, the instrument is integrated into both graduate and undergraduate curricula, as well as UNC’s Summer Undergraduate Research Opportunity in Chemistry (SUROC), which serves as an NSF REU Site. Furthermore, the instrument facilitates interdisciplinary research by hosting annual X-ray crystallography symposiums that cover topics in both small- and macromolecular research, fostering stimulating discussions across disciplines.

The advanced capabilities of the instrument have also attracted many prospective students to the department.  Additionally, the acquisition of the Bruker D8 VENTURE has initiated the development of a core personnel training program within the department, aimed at trained graduate students interested in pursuing careers in service crystallography.
